articles.headline: In Reversal, House G.O.P. Agrees to Lift Debt Limit
articles.snippet: Republicans said they would back down on the borrowing limit to open a window for Congress to pass a budget and begin talks on long-term deficit reduction.
articles.abstract: Republicans said they would back down on the borrowing limit to open a window for Congress to pass a budget and begin talks on long-term deficit reduction.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Backing down from their hard-line stance, House Republicans said Friday that they would agree to lift the federal government’s statutory borrowing limit for three months, with a requirement that both chambers of Congress pass a budget in that time to clear the way for negotiations on long-term deficit reduction.

articles.headline: Finding Advice for More Modest Retirement Investments
articles.snippet: More companies are popping up to help the vast majority of people who have at most several hundred thousand dollars to invest when they retire.
articles.abstract: More companies are popping up to help the vast majority of people who have at most several hundred thousand dollars to invest when they retire.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re perfectly capable of running your own retirement savings, selecting the right mix of low-cost investments, rebalancing at the right time and not buying and selling out of fear or greed, then good for you.

articles.headline: Boeing Closer to an Answer, but Not to Getting 787s Back in the Air
articles.snippet: It is possible that the Dreamliner’s batteries were overcharged, but to lift a grounding order, Boeing must demonstrate that it can prevent similar episodes from happening.
articles.abstract: It is possible that the Dreamliner’s batteries were overcharged, but to lift a grounding order, Boeing must demonstrate that it can prevent similar episodes from happening.
articles.lead_paragraph: With 787 Dreamliners grounded around the world, Boeing is scrambling to devise a technical fix that would allow the planes to fly again soon, even as investigators in the United States and Japan are trying to figure out what caused the plane’s lithium-ion batteries to overheat.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Well-Trod Path: Political Donor to Ambassador
articles.snippet: Many of those who collectively raised more than a billion dollars to elect President Obama are also would-be diplomats, engaged in a scramble for about 30 plum embassy posts.
articles.abstract: Many of those who collectively raised more than a billion dollars to elect President Obama are also would-be diplomats, engaged in a scramble for about 30 plum embassy posts.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Obama hosted dozens of his top donors at the White House in late November for a celebratory post-election dinner of chicken and pumpkin pie, few in the room could claim to have done more to elect him than Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue magazine.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Search Option From Facebook Is a Privacy Test
articles.snippet: Whether Facebook’s users will continue to divulge even more private details will determine whether so-called social search is the next step in how we navigate the online world.
articles.abstract: Whether Facebook’s users will continue to divulge even more private details will determine whether so-called social search is the next step in how we navigate the online world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook’s greatest triumph has been to persuade a seventh of the world’s population to share their personal lives online.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Hostages Dead in Bloody Climax to Siege in Algeria
articles.snippet: The Algerian Army conducted a last assault on a gas field that militants had seized, killing most of the kidnappers left, and raising the total of hostages dead to at least 23, Algerian officials said.
articles.abstract: The Algerian Army conducted a last assault on a gas field that militants had seized, killing most of the kidnappers left, and raising the total of hostages dead to at least 23, Algerian officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — The four-day hostage crisis in the Sahara reached a bloody conclusion on Saturday as the Algerian Army carried out a final assault on the gas field taken over by Islamist militants, killing most of the remaining kidnappers and raising the total of hostages killed to at least 23, Algerian officials said.

articles.headline: The Guns Hiding in Your Portfolio
articles.snippet: Whatever their position on gun control, many investors own shares of firearms makers at least indirectly, through their mutual and exchange-traded funds.
articles.abstract: Whatever their position on gun control, many investors own shares of firearms makers at least indirectly, through their mutual and exchange-traded funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you comb through your 401(k) carefully enough, there is a good chance you’ll find something startling: a stock that returned more than 80 percent over the last year.

articles.headline: How to Cut Megabanks Down to Size
articles.snippet: Chopping the biggest banks into pieces would better protect the nation’s taxpayers, says the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.
articles.abstract: Chopping the biggest banks into pieces would better protect the nation’s taxpayers, says the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT is a prevailing myth in Washington: big bailouts are over for good. Never again, the line goes, could giant financial institutions imperil the nation’s economy.

articles.headline: Buying the N.Y.S.E., in One Shot
articles.snippet: A bold deal by the owner of IntercontinentalExchange to acquire the New York Stock Exchange shows how technology is transforming the world’s markets.
articles.abstract: A bold deal by the owner of IntercontinentalExchange to acquire the New York Stock Exchange shows how technology is transforming the world’s markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN nearly all else had failed, Jeffrey C. Sprecher flew to New York City and crashed at his sisters’ apartment, a cramped walk-up on the Upper West Side, one flight above a noisy bar.

articles.headline: Fiscal Footnote: Big Senate Gift to Drug Maker
articles.snippet: A provision buried in the fiscal bill passed earlier this month gives Amgen, the world’s largest biotechnology firm, more time to sell a lucrative kidney dialysis drug without price restraints.
articles.abstract: A provision buried in the fiscal bill passed earlier this month gives Amgen, the world’s largest biotechnology firm, more time to sell a lucrative kidney dialysis drug without price restraints.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just two weeks after pleading guilty in a major federal fraud case, Amgen, the world’s largest biotechnology firm, scored a largely unnoticed coup on Capitol Hill: Lawmakers inserted a paragraph into the “fiscal cliff” bill that did not mention the company by name but strongly favored one of its drugs.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Kevin Sack

articles.headline: Jihadists’ Surge in North Africa Reveals Grim Side of Arab Spring
articles.snippet: The assaults in Mali and Algeria have contributed to a sense that North Africa, long a dormant backwater for Al Qaeda, is turning into another zone of dangerous instability.
articles.abstract: The assaults in Mali and Algeria have contributed to a sense that North Africa, long a dormant backwater for Al Qaeda, is turning into another zone of dangerous instability.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the uprising closed in around him, the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi warned that if he fell, chaos and holy war would overtake North Africa. “Bin Laden’s people would come to impose ransoms by land and sea,” he told reporters. “We will go back to the time of Redbeard, of pirates, of Ottomans imposing ransoms on boats.”

articles.headline: Military Rules Leave Gay Spouses Out in Cold
articles.snippet: Because same-sex marriages are not recognized by the military, gay service members who are married are barred from receiving benefits accorded to heterosexual married couples.
articles.abstract: Because same-sex marriages are not recognized by the military, gay service members who are married are barred from receiving benefits accorded to heterosexual married couples.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANFORD, N. C. — Nakisha Hardy spent the first nine months of her marriage on a remote Army base in Afghanistan, a tour of duty punctuated by sporadic mortar blasts and constant e-mails to her spouse back home.

articles.headline: Change Comes: After 4 Years, Friends See Shifts in the Obamas
articles.snippet: The Obamas have gained and lost in their four years in the White House, becoming seasoned professionals instead of newcomers, yet many close to them see the tolls their roles have taken.
articles.abstract: The Obamas have gained and lost in their four years in the White House, becoming seasoned professionals instead of newcomers, yet many close to them see the tolls their roles have taken.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barack and Michelle Obama have spent more than a thousand days on display before the nation’s eyes, but the personal changes they have undergone can be hard to detect.

articles.headline: Algerians Find Many More Dead at Hostage Site
articles.snippet: Algerian officials said on Sunday that the preliminary count of 23 dead hostages from the four-day siege at a gas-production complex in the Sahara seemed certain to rise.
articles.abstract: Algerian officials said on Sunday that the preliminary count of 23 dead hostages from the four-day siege at a gas-production complex in the Sahara seemed certain to rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — Algerian officials said Sunday that security forces combing the scene of a bloody four-day hostage siege had discovered many more corpses, some badly burned, at a gas-production complex deep in the Sahara.

articles.headline: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
articles.snippet: The quiet ceremony before Monday’s public pomp, forced by a quirk of the constitutional calendar, started President Obama’s second term with a divided government at home and persistent threats abroad.
articles.abstract: The quiet ceremony before Monday’s public pomp, forced by a quirk of the constitutional calendar, started President Obama’s second term with a divided government at home and persistent threats abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With only his family beside him, Barack Hussein Obama was sworn into office for a second term on Sunday in advance of Monday’s public pomp, facing a bitterly divided government at home and persistent threats abroad that inhibit his effort to redefine America’s use of power.

articles.headline: Swarming a Book Online
articles.snippet: Angry fans bombarded Amazon with dozens of negative reviews of a new biography of Michael Jackson and  got several favorable notices erased.
articles.abstract: Angry fans bombarded Amazon with dozens of negative reviews of a new biography of Michael Jackson and  got several favorable notices erased.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reviews on Amazon are becoming attack weapons, intended to sink new books as soon as they are published.

articles.headline: Dreamliner Troubles Put Boeing on Edge
articles.snippet: If the issue with smoldering batteries proves more complicated, it could threaten plans to expand production of the planes, and the jobs that go with them.
articles.abstract: If the issue with smoldering batteries proves more complicated, it could threaten plans to expand production of the planes, and the jobs that go with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until smoldering batteries forced safety regulators to ground Boeing’s new 787 Dreamliner jets last week, the aircraft manufacturer was flying high, with soaring profits and a recently regained No. 1 ranking in jet deliveries over Airbus.

articles.headline: A Downsized Boston Globe Opens Its Space for Community Uses
articles.snippet: As newspaper staffs and revenues shrink, executives are seeking creative ways to use unoccupied office space.
articles.abstract: As newspaper staffs and revenues shrink, executives are seeking creative ways to use unoccupied office space.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Among the many changes that Christopher M. Mayer wanted to make when he became publisher of The Boston Globe in 2010 was to transform a particularly unattractive section of the newsroom.

articles.headline: An Overture From China Is Yet to Win Hollywood
articles.snippet: The Dalian Wanda Group in China bought AMC Entertainment for $2.6 billion in September, then said it would seek $10 billion in new deals. So far, nothing.
articles.abstract: The Dalian Wanda Group in China bought AMC Entertainment for $2.6 billion in September, then said it would seek $10 billion in new deals. So far, nothing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In September, Wang Jianlin, the chairman and president of China’s Dalian Wanda Group, told a news conference here of his plans to invest at least $10 billion in both entertainment and commercial properties in the United States.

articles.headline: Mixed Response to Comcast in Expanding Net Access
articles.snippet: As Comcast’s Internet Essentials program to bring affordable broadband to low-income homes gains popularity, the company has been accused of overreaching in its interactions with local communities.
articles.abstract: As Comcast’s Internet Essentials program to bring affordable broadband to low-income homes gains popularity, the company has been accused of overreaching in its interactions with local communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — At the cramped downtown office of the Community and Economic Development Association of Cook County, a line of older residents waited to apply for a federal program that helps pay for heat and other utilities. On the walls, next to posters advertising Head Start and other public services, hung posters for something called Internet Essentials.

articles.headline: How M.I.T. Ensnared a Hacker, Bucking a Freewheeling Culture
articles.snippet: M.I.T.’s decision to catch a person illegally downloading content led to charges of computer and wire fraud against Aaron Swartz, who died of an apparent suicide.
articles.abstract: M.I.T.’s decision to catch a person illegally downloading content led to charges of computer and wire fraud against Aaron Swartz, who died of an apparent suicide.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early days of 2011, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology learned that it had an intruder. Worse, it believed the intruder had been there before.

articles.headline: Among Blacks, Pride Is Mixed With Expectations for Obama
articles.snippet: African-Americans remain overwhelmingly supportive of President Obama, but many have higher expectations for his second term.
articles.abstract: African-Americans remain overwhelmingly supportive of President Obama, but many have higher expectations for his second term.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Greggory L. Brown, a 59-year-old pastor of a small Lutheran church, committed himself to ministry and a life pursuing social justice on April 4, 1968 — the day the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was slain by an assassin’s bullet.

articles.headline: North Africa Is a New Test
articles.snippet: In taking on the militants in the region, Western nations are confronting multinational bands that are often able to move with relative freedom across porous borders.
articles.abstract: In taking on the militants in the region, Western nations are confronting multinational bands that are often able to move with relative freedom across porous borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The bloody resolution of the hostage crisis in Algeria has brought into focus the broader challenges the United States and its allies face in confronting terrorist cells that have taken up sanctuary across northern Africa.

articles.headline: Algeria Defends Tough Response to Hostage Crisis as Toll Rises
articles.snippet: The prime minister of Algeria said that the militants behind the kidnappings intended to kill all their captives and that the army saved many from death by attacking.
articles.abstract: The prime minister of Algeria said that the militants behind the kidnappings intended to kill all their captives and that the army saved many from death by attacking.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — The prime minister of Algeria offered an unapologetic defense on Monday of the country’s tough actions to end the Sahara hostage crisis, saying that the militants who had carried out the kidnappings intended to kill all their captives and that the army saved many from death by attacking.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: ‘We Must Act’
articles.snippet: President Obama used his inaugural address to define his version of liberalism, with an emphasis on expanding opportunity.
articles.abstract: President Obama used his inaugural address to define his version of liberalism, with an emphasis on expanding opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Barack Hussein Obama ceremonially opened his second term on Monday with an assertive Inaugural Address that offered a robust articulation of modern liberalism in America, arguing that “preserving our individual freedoms ultimately requires collective action.”
